If average revenue is less average variable cost, the firm's losses are greater than its fixed
costs, and it will minimize its losses by shutting down production in the short run. In
this case (a price less than P, in Figure 5), the loss from continuing to operate is greater
than the loss (total fixed costs) if the firm is shut down.
In the long run, all costs are variable, so a firm can avoid its (short-run) fixed costs by
shutting down. For this reason, if price is expected to remain below minimum average
total cost (Point A in Figure 5) in the long run, the firm will shut down rather than
continue to generate losses.
